titleStmt.title: Frequency and predictors of acute ischemic Lesions on Brain MRI in young Patients with a clinical Diagnosis of TIA

analytic.title: Frequency and predictors of acute ischemic Lesions on Brain MRI in young Patients with a clinical Diagnosis of TIA

biblStruct.note: Received Date : 21-Sep-2015 Revised Date : 24-Jan-2016 Accepted Date : 01-Mar-2016

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: This is the author manuscript accepted for publication and has undergone full peer review but has not been through the copyediting, typesetting, pagination and proofreading process, which may lead to differences between this version and the Version of Record.
Please cite this article as
A transient ischemic attack (TIA) is defined as an episode with neurological deficits caused by temporary brain ischemia lasting less than 24 hours [1,2].
Although it might seem harmless, a TIA is prognostically relevant, as it indicates an increased risk for subsequent cerebrovascular events [3].
This risk might increase dramatically in those TIA patients with acute ischemic lesions, as observed on diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) on brain MRI [4,5].
Recent studies on young stroke patients provided detailed information on age and gender distribution, risk factors, etiologic factors, and imaging findings [6,7].
They emphasized the limitation in translating knowledge from general stroke populations to the specific subgroup of younger stroke patients [8].

Therefore, we investigated the frequency of and clinical parameters associated with the detection of DWI-lesions in young TIA patients included in the "Stroke in Young Fabry Patients" study (sifap1), a large multicentre European study on young stroke [9].
To the best of our knowledge, no prior large-scale study has attempted to assess the features of TIA in young patients.

div.head: Design of the study and patients

p.s: The multinational sifap1 study (47 centers in 15 European countries) prospectively recruited (between April 2007 and January 2010) 5023 patients aged 18 to 55 years with a cerebrovascular event (CVE) to establish the prevalence of Fabry disease.
Details of this study have been published previously [6,7,9].
The study was approved by the ethics committees at the leading centre and at each study site.
Each patient or his legal representative gave written informed consent to the participation.

A secondary aim of the sifap1 study was to better characterize patterns of stroke in young patients by collecting a broad range of clinical, laboratory, and radiological data using mandatory strict and standardized methods.
For inclusion in the sifap study, an MRI scan with specified quality requirements was mandatory.
MRI sequences followed optimised stroke imaging protocols at participating centres but were not standardized.
The present secondary analysis aimed to investigate the frequency of acute to identify areas of acute ischemia [12,13].
Old infarcts were defined as areas of T2 hyperintensity with associated focal atrophy and / or containing fluid-filled spaces [12].

White matter hyperintensities (WMHs) were defined as lesions with high signal intensity on T2weighted images in the absence of evidence for complete tissue destruction and were rated according to the Fazekas scale [12].

Deep WMHs were classified as 0=absent, 1=punctuate, 2=early confluent, and 3=confluent; periventricular white matter hyperintensities (PWMH) were categorized as: 0=absent; 1=pencil-thin lining; 2=halo of ≥5mm t hickness; 3=irregular WMH extending into deep white matter [12].
First, we conducted descriptive analyses.
Bivariate analysis was completed to test associations of several characteristics with the presence of DWI lesions in patients with TIA.
A multiple logistics regression analysis was conducted to test which characteristics were independently associated with DWI lesions in TIA patients after adjustment for other covariates.
A stepwise backward procedure was applied.
Only covariates with a p-value<0.1 in bivariate analyses were selected for the multiple regression models.
All p-values were adjusted for center heterogeneity using random effects models.
A two-sided significance level of α=0.05 was
Among the 5023 patients included in the sifap1 study, 1071 patients had a symptom duration <24 hours, consistent with the definition of a TIA.
According to Fazekas et al. 142 patients were excluded due to a MRI taken later than 10 days after the acute event and further 82 patients had a MRI of insufficient quality for interpretation [12].
829 patients who had MRI data satisfying the requirements for the analysis were included in the final analysis.
121 patients (15%) demonstrated an acute DWI lesion (Figure 1, Table 1).
There was no difference in age between patients with DWI lesions versus those without DWI lesions (DWI+ median: 47 years versus DWI-median: 46 years; p=0.569).
Dichotomizing between the youngest age group and the reminder of the cohort did also not yield significant differences in the frequency of DWI lesions [18-35 years: 15/109 (13.8%) versus >35 years:
This article is protected by copyright.
All rights reserved 106/720 (14.7%); p=0.315].
The median time interval between the CVE and brain MRI was 2 days (IQR 1-4 days), (DWI positive: 2 days (IQR 1-4 days) versus DWI negative: 1 day (IQR 1-4 days); p=0.378).
In the majority of the patients the acute lesions were found in the anterior circulation (n=92, 77%), and they occurred predominantly in the cortico-subcortical areas (63/92, 68%).
Seventy one patients had a lesion ≤1cm, 48 presented lesions >1cm.
In 57 patients (47.1%) more than one lesion was identified; among these patients ten (17.5%) had two or more lesions in different territories (Table 1).

In 53 patients (43.8%) a right sided lesion was evident, in 60 patients (49.7%) lesions left sided were detected, 14 patients (11.6%) had a brainstem or cerebellar lesion and 7 patients showed bilateral lesions.
73% of the patients with an acute left sided lesion had a left hemispheric clinical presentation; and 43% of these patients presented with a right-sided paresis.
In 27 patients DWI lesions and the clinical manifestation were ipsilateral; six of those had lesions bilaterally.
Almost all patients with cerebellar lesions had vertigo as a presenting symptom (6/7) (Table 2).

Comparing TIA patients with acute DWI lesions to those without any acute lesions, acute lesions were associated with left hemispheric presenting symptoms, dysarthria as presenting symptom, stroke aetiology, and old infarctions as demonstrated by MRI (table 3a and 3b).
Patients with acute DWI lesions more often had a cardioembolic aetiology or large artery atherosclerosis causing the current event (cardioembolism: 19.5% vs. 10.1%,
p=0.005; largeartery sclerosis: 14.4% versus 8.1%, p=0.005).
In a subgroup of patients (n=446), ultrasound data on brain supplying arteries had been documented within this sifap cohort.
Regarding the frequency of vessel stenosis, there were no differences between patients with a DWI lesion versus those without a DWI lesion (Table 3a).
Old infarctions in the brain MRI were identified in 143 patients (17.2%).

A previous cerebrovascular event (including TIA and brain infarction) was more often evident in patients with old infarctions in the brain MRI (78/140, 55.7% versus 139/680, 20.4%; P<0.001); in 62/140 (44.3%) patients with old infarctions on brain MRI no previous CVE was documented.

Using a multiple logistic regression analysis, the following parameters were identified as independent predictors for an acute lesion: left hemispheric presenting symptoms (OR 1.92, CI: 1.27 ─ 2.91), dysarthria as presenting symptom (OR 2.17, CI: 1.38 ─ 3.43) and old infarctions as demonstrated by MRI (territories of the middle and posterior cerebral artery: OR: 2.43, CI: 1.42 ─ 4.15; OR: 2.41, CI: 1.02 ─ 5.69, respectively) (Table 4).
This article is protected by copyright.
All rights reserved Our study demonstrated a regular DWI scan is the common finding in young TIA patients.
In 15% of young stroke patients with symptoms suggestive of a CVE lasting <24 hours, hence clinically classified as TIA, an acute lesion in the DWI was identified.
Apart from left hemispheric presenting symptoms there was a weak association between clinical presentation and the lesion location.
Characteristics associated with acute DWI lesions were: left hemispheric presenting symptoms, dysarthria, and old infarctions on the brain MRI.
Because of the lack of research in this specific area, no previous investigations of exclusively young stroke patients are available for direct comparison.
When discussing our findings we therefore need to refer to data derived from studies addressing general stroke populations.
The lower yield of DWI lesions in this particular population compared to elderly TIA patient populations is an interesting finding.

Conceptually, several potential explanations could be raised (e.g. that DWI lesions already had disappeared, that not enough cytotoxic oedema had formed because of short duration of ischemia, that part of clinically diagnosed TIA's were not caused by an ischemic event or that the quality of the DWI sequences was suboptimal) which will be discussed subsequently.
According to the literature there is a large variety in the prevalence of DWI lesions in acute TIA patients [14].
A potential cause of this observation may be the procedural TIA definition.
Some authors claim a clinical TIA with acute lesions may be classified as stroke, thereby modifying proportions by placing TIAs into stroke subgroups [14,15].
Previous research has shown that acute lesions in TIAs could be expected in 30-40% of the cases, yet the prevalence in our specific group of young TIAs is low [14].
This result could be attributed to the fact we investigated specifically a group of young TIA patients which is not comparable to studies specified in the literature [14].
On the other hand, this result could reflect accurate findings.

In our study the bias in adjudication clinical TIAs with acute lesions to strokes can be considered low because in the case report form in the sifap1 study we simply asked for the duration of the clinical manifestation.
To what extent TIAs without DWI lesions represent TIA mimics rather than a result of a cerebrovascular event remains unclear.
When interpreting our results this general problem, which inevitably occurs when investigating patients with TIA, needs to be taken into account [16].
A further bias influencing the detection of acute lesions in the DWI might be the time delay between the current event to the MRI examination [17].

However this aspect should not have influenced our results to a greater extent, as no relevant differences with regard to the time delay were observed between DWI positive versus DWI negative patients.
In line with this observation Brazzelli et al. found in a meta-analysis no impact of increasing time delay from
This article is protected by copyright.
All rights reserved event to the MRI regarding the proportion of DWI positive patients.
Instead, the most important factor influencing the rates of DWI positive patients was the sample size [14].
Large populations (n ≥200) had fewer rates of DWI positive patients [14].
This is in accordance with our results as with 829 subjects our study is the largest investigation on this issue.
The parameter of left hemispheric presenting symptoms was associated with acute lesions; a left hemispheric lesion presented with a left hemispheric symptom in 73% of the cases.
However, in accordance with a previous investigation by van Rooij et al. [18], in a considerable proportion of our patients the clinical presentation did not match the lesion location.
This result suggests that acute lesions in TIA patients might rather indicate a general embolic arterial ischemic activity accompanying the acute cerebrovascular event.

This conclusion is also supported by the fact that the occurrence of DWI lesions in our patients was associated with embolic stroke aetiologies including stroke subtypes of cardioembolism and large artery atherosclerosis.
Both aetiologies are known to cause embolic infarction pattern in the acute DWI, with some of the lesions without clinical correlates [19,20].

In addition, in half of our patients (47.1%) more than one DWI lesion (partially in different vascular territories) was evident, the majority of them were small (1cm) and located in the cortical or subcortical regions, which is also suggestive of embolic pattern [19][20][21].
In accordance with this hypothesis, other authors suspected DWI lesions in TIA patients might be cerebrovascular "footprints" of a cardiac disorder causing embolic events [22].
Old infarctions in brain MRI were noted more often in TIA patients with acute DWI lesions.

While the evidence regarding the prognostic relevance of acute lesions in TIA patients is still controversial, this observation indicates the duplicity of a pathomechanism, which already had caused former ischemic brain injury [4,5].
This provides indirect evidence for a prognostic value of imaging-proven brain infarctions in predicting future cerebrovascular events.

While Anticoli and colleagues recently failed to identify such a prognostic relevance for acute lesions in TIA patients, Ay and co-workers found a higher predictive value of subsequent strokes for acute DWI lesion in TIA patients in comparison to a simply narrative test such as the ABCD 2 score [4,5].
An ABCD 2 score ≥4 showed a 4.65 fold increased risk for a subsequent stroke, in contrast a DWI lesion alone determined an 11.1 fold increase [4].
ABCD 2 scores <4 represents a risk for a recurrent stroke of less than 1%, at this stage an additional DWI lesion increases this value to 4.9%.
This needs to be taken into account, as ABCD 2 scores <4 with acute DWI lesions apply to a considerable proportion (9%) of TIAs.
Therefore, considering the ABCD 2 score alone would lead to an underestimation of the
This article is protected by copyright.
All rights reserved recurrence risk in these patients [4].

Nevertheless the ABDC 2 Since some studies identified the symptom duration of a TIA relevant for the long term prognosis as well as an important determinant for DWI lesions in TIAs, this missing information in our study represents a limitation [4,5,26].
Furthermore, although the sifap study documented a comprehensive data set, information on substance abuse is not available.

This aspect needs to be taken into account regarding the identification of etiologic factors, since especially among young individuals substance abuse may be more strongly implicated in the stroke pathogenesis [27].
Along the same lines, the use of transcranial doppler ultrasound for detection of microembolic signals would have usefully augmented the diagnostic-workup.
However, this approach was not followed routinely within the sifap study.
Similarly, the documentation of ultrasound studies of the brain supplying arteries was not undertaken constantly.

However, in a smaller subset of patients, we did not find a correlation between the presence of a vessel stenosis and DWI lesions, except for a trend for a higher frequency of ICA occlusions in the DWI positive group.
However, in the interpretation of these findings, the small number of events in these subgroups has to be considered.

With regard to the diagnosis of acute ischemic brain lesions on MRI, the three imaging raters also used ADC maps to confirm DWI positive lesions via focal ADC restriction (and thus to distinguish lesions from "shine-through" effects or vasogenic oedema), but no quantitative measurements were done as sequences had not been standardized within sifap.
score was addressed in numerous publications, boosting its reputation [3,5,23,24].

As clinical TIAs might result in an acute ischemic brain injury, potentially not correlated to the clinical presentation and most likely of embolic origin, the MRI should be prioritized in the acute delivery of care.
The concept of establishing a diagnosis of a TIA solely based on clinical aspects has been challenged by cases with a clinical diagnosis of TIA and acute DWI lesions on MRI.
Therefore, given the implications for prognosis, a tissue-based definition of TIAs has been suggested e.g. by Giles and co-authors [25].
Future studies might therefore wish to follow this approach.
In summary, in a small proportion (15%) of young TIA patients a DWI lesion was found.
Most of the lesions were located in the cortical or subcortical region and were not associated with the clinical presentation, suggesting an embolic origin for the actual cerebrovascular event.
TIAs with acute DWI lesions were associated with old infarctions on brain MRI, indicating a recurrent stroke mechanism.
As acute ischemic lesions with TIA are of significant value in predicting future events and cannot be predicted on clinical grounds, early brain MRI examination is warranted in these patients.

considered.
No adjustment for multiple testing was applied.
